title: RL33042
content: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) was created by the Homeland Security Act of 2002, leading to a significant reorganization of the executive branch. Similar to the Department of Defense (DOD), which underwent structural changes since its establishment in 1947, DHS was formed through legislative compromises. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to reorganize functions and units within DHS as needed, as outlined in Section 872 of the Homeland Security Act. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 granted the President temporary authority to reorganize DHS, leading to the creation of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection and the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement within the department's Border and Transportation Security Directorate. DHS was initially organized with the office of the Secretary/Deputy Secretary at the center and individual directorates for management. The Department of Homeland Security was organized with individual directorates for management, science and technology, information analysis, border security, and emergency response. Other units within the department reported directly to the Secretary, including the Coast Guard and Secret Service. DHS had approximately 170,000 employees, with a significant field organization. In March 2005, Michael Chertoff initiated a comprehensive review of the Department of Homeland Security's organization and operations. This effort involved 18 action teams and over 250 staff members evaluating specific issues and seeking input from public and private partners. The Department of Homeland Security conducted a comprehensive review in 2005, seeking input from various partners. This resulted in a six-point agenda focusing on preparedness, border security, transportation security, information sharing, stewardship improvement, and organizational realignment. Specific policy initiatives will be launched in key areas in the future. In July 2005, Secretary Chertoff announced structural changes at DHS to improve mission performance, including the formation of a new policy office, improvements in intelligence sharing, an operations coordination office, and a consolidation effort for the Department's preparedness mission. Secretary Chertoff proposed the creation of a central policy office led by an Under Secretary for Policy at DHS to strengthen the department's ability to develop vital policies. This idea builds upon previous work and recommendations for consolidating policy analysis and development offices under the direction of such an officer. The recommendation for the creation of an Office of Policy, Planning, and International Affairs at DHS was reiterated in a December 2004 report and supported by Senator Susan Collins. This proposed office, headed by an Assistant Secretary, would oversee strategic policy development and program oversight. The Office of Policy, Planning, and International Affairs at DHS is responsible for strategic policy development and oversight of program policy efforts, including economic, regulatory, legislative, and foreign policy analysis functions. The Policy Review Board evaluates and promotes developing policies, ensuring consistency with strategic goals and priorities. House appropriators approved $8.7 million for OPPIA, while Senate appropriators recommended $7.25 million and expected it to assume functions of the Operational Integration Staff. The Senate approved funding for the Office of Policy, Planning, and International Affairs (OPPIA) at DHS, but there was a discrepancy in expectations regarding its role compared to the Operational Integration Staff. Secretary Chertoff notified Congress of reorganization plans within DHS in July 2005. Secretary Chertoff announced plans to establish the Office of Policy, Planning, and International Affairs (OPPIA) under Homeland Security, with the intention to implement changes on October 1, 2005. He requested legislation to elevate the Assistant Secretary to an Under Secretary position to lead the Directorate for Policy. Various organizational units will be relocated to this new centralized policy office, including the Office of International Affairs and the Border and Transportation Security Policy and Planning Office. Additionally, a strategic policy planning office and a refugee policy coordinator will be established. In July 2005, Secretary Chertoff announced the establishment of a new policy apparatus within Homeland Security, including a strategic policy planning office and a refugee policy coordinator. The Assistant Secretary for Information Analysis will become the Chief Intelligence Officer, leading a strengthened Information Analysis division. This division will ensure coordination, fusion, and analysis of intelligence within the Department, serving as a primary connection between DHS and the intelligence community. The Homeland Security Act vested the Assistant Secretary for Information Analysis with the duty to access, receive, and analyze intelligence information to identify and assess terrorist threats. However, this provision was undermined when President George W. Bush announced the creation of the Terrorist Threat Integration Center in 2003. The creation of the Terrorist Threat Integration Center (TTIC) in 2003 by DHS and DOD aimed to merge and analyze all threat information in one place, potentially overshadowing the role of the Assistant Secretary for Information Analysis. TTIC was responsible for terrorism analysis, except for purely domestic terrorism, while IAIP focused on assessing threats and vulnerabilities to the nation. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 transferred TTIC to the National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC), designated as the primary organization for analyzing and integrating all intelligence related to terrorism and counterterrorism. NCTC is responsible for strategic operational planning for counterterrorism activities and coordinating with various departments and agencies. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 led to the creation of the National Counter Terrorism Center (NCTC) and the Terrorist Screening Center (TSC). The House and Senate Committees on Appropriations directed the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to review the mission and functions of IAIP in light of these changes and provide a report on its future role in the intelligence community. Based on a comparative review of IAIP's intelligence responsibilities pre and post the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, Secretary Chertoff highlighted the need to elevate IAIP's Information Analysis resources to a stand-alone office due to the department's multiple intelligence offices. Secretary Chertoff emphasized the need for the Information Analysis unit to be a stand-alone office within DHS, reporting directly to the Secretary. The Office of Cyber Security and Telecommunications (OCST) will coordinate Department-wide activities on cyber threats and infrastructure, supporting telecommunications infrastructure for national security and emergency communications needs. This aligns with the Department of Homeland Security's reorganization efforts to address cyber security threats effectively. In a reorganization notification letter to Congress on July 13, 2005, the Secretary announced the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center would become a standalone entity reporting directly to the Deputy Secretary. The Federal Air Marshal Service would be transferred from Immigration and Customs Enforcement to TSA by October 1, 2005. Additionally, the Secretary planned to merge the Offices of Legislative Affairs and State and Local Government Coordination and Preparedness Office into a new Office of Legislative and Intergovernmental Affairs (OLIA) to improve responses to Congressional inquiries. The Office of the National Capital Region Coordination will now report through the Under Secretary for Preparedness to enhance preparedness planning for the Capital, including biopreparedness planning. The Secretary views this as enhancing the office's ability to influence preparedness functions directly related to protecting the country's Capital. A suggested merger of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) did not materialize, with some experts opposing the idea and the acting DHS Inspector General asked to study the issue. Section 872 of the Homeland Security Act allows the Secretary to reorganize the Department by reallocating functions and establishing or consolidating organizational units. Senator Collins and Senator Lieberman expressed concerns about the broad scope of the Secretary's reorganization authority. The Homeland Security Act allows the Secretary to reorganize the Department by reallocating functions and establishing or consolidating organizational units, subject to limitations specified in the section. The term "organizational units" is not clearly defined in the act, but it appears Congress intended them to be smaller than agencies or other statutorily created entities. Congress suggests that an organizational unit may be smaller than an agency or entity, as seen in the Homeland Security Act. Secretary Chertoff's reorganization proposal raised issues regarding the leadership composition at DHS, with concerns about appointment authority and compensation levels for new positions. It was unclear if the Secretary had the authority to establish these positions without congressional action, as Congress has the power to create departments and agencies and delegate organizational responsibilities. Congress determines the leadership hierarchy and accountability of departments by establishing top positions in law. This includes appointing officers with Senate approval (PAS positions) or by the President alone (PA positions). Creating leadership positions as PAS positions allows Senators to be involved in nominee selection and fitness evaluation. Confirmation hearings provide Senators with a role in selecting nominees and assessing their suitability for the position. It also allows for oversight of agencies and programs, and ensures nominees will appear before Congress when requested. This commitment obtained during confirmation makes it easier for Congress to call upon officials for testimony. In some cases, Congress assigns appointment authority to the President for positions in the White House Office, where officials act as advisers. The Homeland Security Act created seven such positions in the new department, giving Congress less influence over appointments. In other cases, appointment authority is given to the Secretary, commonly for lower-level officers. The evolution of DHS has led to the creation of three categories of assistant secretaries. The assistant secretary title is used in three categories within the Department of Homeland Security: those appointed with Senate advice and consent, those presidentially appointed without advice and consent, and those appointed by the Secretary without Senate input. This varied usage is uncommon in other departments, raising questions about the level of policymaking authority and responsibility each category holds. Senate-confirmed assistant secretaries undergo greater scrutiny and are more accountable to Congress, while those appointed without Senate involvement may have differing stature within the department and government.
